Summary I am a London based designer with expertise mainly in Experience Design and Digital Branding Strategy, I have worked in creative agencies for most of my professional life. 
In 2010 I joined the Thomson Reuters UX Design Team, where I have worked as UX Art Director and then UX Creative Director, leading the Creative Direction Team of five designers with different backgrounds, with the objective to conceive and design the new generation of Thomson Reuters F&R Digital products. 
I was part of the UX Design team at the BBC in 2012 and earlier this year, where I had the opportunity to work on My BBC and BBC One service. Technical Documentation, Client and System Testing, Account Boarding Systems Experience VP, Business Technology Liaison Pershing, a BNY Mellon company August 2015  – Present (1 month) Director, Project Management / IT Systems First Data Corporation February 2012  – Present (3 years 7 months) New York - Spearheaded and marketed strategic business solutions to build new and automate existing products supporting the U.S. domestic and international merchants, increase growth, and optimize revenue for the Leasing and Cash Advance business units of First Data.  
- Worked as a SME and cross-functional business liaison to develop and manage new products throughout life cycles, promote operational change, new revenue streams, and process improvements to achieve aggressive and sustainable growth targets.  
- Oversaw the planning, development, implementation, and tracking of all strategic projects, domestic and international, suitable for multiple platforms including mobile devices: front-end internet facing boarding systems for internal teams and external clients, complex online reporting, data storage systems and all their data feeds to and from other internal and external sources, as well as their connections to back-end databases. 
- Partnered with business units, stakeholders, vendors, sales, and IT to create, implement and optimize enterprise wide solutions in the merchant boarding market.  
- Produced detailed project plans with milestones and structured timelines to manage senior leadership’s expectations. 
- Managed multiple projects concurrently with high visibility to executive teams, navigated across all levels of a complex global organization; lead weekly calls, action items and tracked project status with internal and external clients and business partners, vendors, on-shore and off-shore teams.  
- Closely worked with project sponsors and business decision-makers to define the scope of the projects and to review the preliminary requirements. Closely worked with multiple IT teams for product development, testing, roll-out and post-implementation support.  
- Performed on-going program maintenance, developed, and tracked key performance indicators. Sr. Project Manager / IT Systems First Data Corporation February 2007  –  February 2012  (5 years 1 month) New York - Conceptualized and managed home grown products and IT solutions for First Data Global Leasing business unit for major revenue generating systems. Led all aspects of product development and implementation including discovery, business requirements and analysis, reviewing detail designs, outlining test cases, implementing, testing, training users, rolling out, post-implementation, enhancements, and product support: 
- Identified all the project stakeholders and also existing processes within First Data's systems that could be leveraged for each project. Documented process flows and systems diagrams for proper integration. 
- Gathered and translated business needs from end users into business and functional requirements, analyzed business process flows and suggested areas of improvements and efficiencies based on already existing functionalities. 
- Organized and facilitated planning sessions to introduce product requirements to software engineering. Created mock-up screens and designed the user interfaces, analyzed and applied business rules to data elements collected, and documented field mappings. 
- Managed, tracked and enforced requirements throughout the project lifecycle. Defined and documented additional business requirements whenever necessary. Coordinated test plans and test cases, and trained users for systems roll out. Systems Manager First Data Corporation February 2005  –  February 2007  (2 years 1 month) New York - Managed the front-end systems for terminal leasing in First Data. Worked with the entire Global Leasing organization's suite of products in the design, development, implementation and maintenance of new and existing business applications. 
- Worked closely with customers, vendors, business analysts and application development project teams in order to resolve information flow and content issues for Leasing systems. Edited content for the web projects implementing appropriate user centered content design/layout, best practices for usability. 
- Interfaced with internal and external Clients to determine scope of work being performed and issue resolution. Provide expertise in designing solutions for custom requirements. Identifies opportunities to streamline procedures, enhance revenue, and improve product efficiency.  
- Identified and recommended content changes to meet the business strategies and expectations. Managed the content management tool, including training new users and communicating with existing users. 
- Provided direction and management to ensure that enhancements and modifications to the system adhere to all System and Business Development Methodology and Quality of Service Standards  
- Set strategies for enhancements associated with existing products. This includes evaluating, defining, and launching/re-launching new or existing functionalities and enhancements with the purpose of increasing First Data's revenue and customer retention, managing enhancement requests and other improvements. Application Architect First Data Corporation December 2002  –  February 2005  (2 years 3 months) New York - Provided IT solutions for the eCommerce group of First Data for the merchant boarding web systems by managing various aspects of application delivery including: gathering user requirements, design, front-end coding, creating application process flow diagrams, testing and implementation.  
- Worked with project managers, business analysts, development and QA testing teams to develop project work proposals, while ensuring that related projects remained synchronized. 
- Designed the user interfaces, screen flows and navigation, created the web design and graphics for all web based applications, coded the front-end business rules for field validation and cross-reference logic 
- Performed extensive QA validation at the application level and participated in post implementation reviews to ensure user satisfaction. User Experience Designer Intel Corporation April 2000  –  December 2002  (2 years 9 months) Portland, Oregon - Responsible for designing and creating user interfaces for video content delivered on multiple platforms such as Internet, set top boxes, mobile devices. Produced the entire visual content for applications from graphics, screen layout, navigation, web design, and enforced usability rules for a proper user experience.

As we carry around more electronic gadgets, we also carry around more cables. Earphone cords and mobile phone charging cables are must haves, for example. It is annoying when our cables become intertwined and tangled in our bag. Pop-up Cord Wrap aims to resolve the problem of the storage and management of cables, so they stay organised and tangle-free for easy access when needed. 
This relatively flat and compact cord wrap contains three compartments for different sizes of cable. The top layer has a small opening in which to wedge the connector. Made of rubber, Pop-up Cord Wrap pops up to allow for the coiling of the cables and pushes back to store them neatly. Whichever layer you need, just push it out to use. Pop-up Cord Wrap is soft yet tough, serving as a protective case. Summary Aunindra has 9+ years of experience in User Experience Methodologies, UID and Usability Engineering. Aunindra is currently working as Lead User Experience Designer at Intel Corporation. He combines creativity and analytical ability in solving user interface problems to provide fresh, practical and usable solutions. He is a Certified Usability Analyst with HFI and scored 83% marks to qualify in the first attempt. 
 
A designer by design, Aunindra gets a high from taking a project from start to the finish line, borrowing from his vast knowledge of processes, delivery mechanisms and innovations in the UI realm across different industry verticals. His strengths include conducting reviews, user research, usability assessment, information architecture and interaction design with the objective of ensuring quality of software solutions from a usability standpoint. 
 
Aunindra is working on cross device products, smart watch concepts and exploring wearable technology. 
In the past, he has lent his services to products, platforms & solutions unit in Infosys, in the arena of requirement gathering, creating and validating superior design concepts, and giving them wings. 
 
He has also worked at client location in USA and India. 
 
Key Clients/Engagements: Baker Hughes Inc., Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Finacle, National Commercial Bank, KSA, pFIzer, British Petroleum, Juniper, Adidas, Walgreens, AT&T, Cambridge University, Cardinal Health, Cathay Pacific, Aditya Birla Financial Service Group. 
 
Aunindra was part of the Infosys Bangalore DC Management Council for four years. He worked on the policy formulation & implementation. He contributed as a member/lead for some of the key initiatives at Infosys Bangalore like Spark program, Instep, CSR etc. He was selected for the 56 member Employee Engagement team (2009-2010) at Infosys, headed by COO to strategize on the employee related issues and policies org-wide. Summary My personal mission is to create products and experiences that make "sense". It is my goal to integrate ergonomic concepts with innovative design principles. I would like to create human-centered designs that integrate technology and culture, while being comfortable, salient, and asthetically appealing. 
 
Currently, I am conducting research in The Human-Centered Computing Lab at Clemson University where I am evaluating user experiences across multiple mediums, in an attempt to get insights on how to make more informed design decisions. Experience Graduate Research Assistant Human Experience Research Lab at The University of Florida August 2014  – Present (1 year 1 month) User Experience Designer, User Experience Researcher Intel Corporation June 2014  –  August 2014  (3 months) Hillsboro, OR Our team created multiple proofs of concept to create immersive user experiences for the news and magazine segment, innovating the way users can consume content. By integrating Intel RealSense Technology and the Perceptual Computing SDK, we enabled 360° panoramic video with touch and gesture interactions. We also innovated ways to curate and annotate this content into a working prototype. We demonstrated our work at the headquarters of a prominent news and media company, securing a commit win for this solution. I used tools such as Balsamiq to create wireframes and sketches that illustrated compelling usages of our technology. I also provided an implementation guide for partner’s existing websites. 
 
During this internship, I was also able to work with a UX Firm (Empir- acle) to perform a Heuristic Evaluation of Mozzilla Firefox. We were tasked with making suggested improvements for ways to optimize the Firefox experience on Intel 2 in 1 devices. Graduate Research Assistant - Human-Centered Computing Lab Clemson University May 2011  –  May 2014  (3 years 1 month) User Experience Designer Intel Corporation May 2013  –  August 2013  (4 months) Santa Clara, CA For my second Intel internship I worked in the Interaction Experience Research group. I was tasked with understanding camera array technology and using that understanding to create meaningful experiences that would get consumers excited about the future of photography and camera arrays. I worked with a team of other engineers to building a working prototype using 9 Go-Pro cameras and a hardware rig. It was my responsibility to also create a presentation that would showcase the array technology, and possible use cases. As the UX designer I brainstormed use cases, scouted locations to capture camera array images for the presentation and created a concept video that would highlight an innovative experience. Lead PEER Mentor Clemson University August 2009  –  May 2013  (3 years 10 months) Clemson, SC Responsible for several minority freshman engineering students, hold weekly meetings to help with their assimilation into college life and assist them with homework while serving as an all around role model (academic and social mentoring). Also responsible for 10 other mentors. UX Intern in the Automotive Solutions Division Intel Corporation May 2012  –  August 2012  (4 months) As an UX intern, I created personas and day-in-the-life narratives which were instrumental in assessing the needs and wants of consumers and providing a foundation to streamline the efforts of various groups within the division. Assessed user experience through first and second hand value-added research, thereby strengthening the validity of market segmentation findings. Finally, developed innovative solutions and defined interactions through the design of use cases for potentially lucrative market segments, which served to supplement the implementation of new technology. Marketing & Communications Intern Maxim Communications Group May 2007  –  January 2009  (1 year 9 months) While at Maxim, I assisted in facilitating and planning community events and brainstorming other marketing efforts around the state of South Carolina for Maxim clients. I was in charge of large mail-outs and data basing (2,000 entities). Additionally, I helped develop and distribute public service announcements and press releases. Summary I like to design with a larger strategy in mind. I think it's for everyone's benefit to work collectively towards a larger, strategic goal or vision. If that vision is looking impossibly cool then we're probably on the right track.  
 
My brain is nothing compared to my brain + your brain. Working collaboratively, inter-disciplinarily, or co-designing with a user or client is my favorite way to design a new product. A team of people will inevitable have better ideas than one person working alone, and I want to work on the good ideas. 
 
Research is awesome for inspiration. There is something really cathartic about taking a mess of post its and turning it into a wall of organized insights. And while I love designing based on these insights, sometimes good ideas can happen without all that research and synthesis. If there is a quicker way of getting to the good stuff, lets design the project around that and leave the huge research study to the complex problems. 
 
The most important thing about a company is people. The people who work there and the customers they help. I believe that good design comes from companies that aim to do good for their customers and that's the kind of place I'd like to work. Summary I like to design with a larger strategy in mind. Honors & Awards Air Optics | Silver Spark Design Awards September 2011 Air Optics is a ski mask with a detachable mouth piece which allows users to breathe under the snow for al long as an hour.  
 
This safety equipment is targeted at amateur to intermediate skiers and snowboarders who want to explore off-track powder and side-country tracks where the risk of becoming buried in the snow is the number one cause of death.  
 
Air Optics requires no training and includes a bluetooth headset linked to the users phone so that users can stay in touch with each other on the slopes and receive audio notifications when their partner falls. Summary I am a passionate user experience designer with over ten years of experience. Because I consider myself an experience designer I look to work on projects that I allow me to think about the holistic nature of a product. Not only to use my talent to create usable, desirable, meaningful products, but to think how it partakes in the larger picture of a person’s context. I thrive in environments where we the team work closely together leveraging each other’s skills to quickly iterate through ideas. It has been essential for me to play a role in various parts of the product lifecycle, from product vision and strategy all the way through getting the product to market. In addition I have led design teams, and managed outside agency work. 
 
Part of what I love to do is to speak about and educate people on the subject of design and building empathy for users. That as led me to become active in not only the design community but also in tech, business, local universities, and start-up community through talks, workshops and mentorships. Summary I am honest, straight-forward, and think about things in context of an ongoing personal search for sincerity and authenticity in the world around me. 
 
As such, I prefer both individuals and groups to know me by my works and/or an in-person experience rather than a trite digital contraption which proffers an inquiry such as, "how would you summarize yourself and your objectives?" 
 
My objectives: aggressive growth, functional and aesthetic improvement of habitable environments, and encouragement of authenticity in all things. Experience User Experience Designer Intel Corporation May 2013  – Present (2 years 4 months) I'm a gentleman, scholar, and UX guy. Beyond that, it's a tall glass of REDACTED. Drink it in. Creative Director Game Lab Oregon February 2013  – Present (2 years 7 months) Portland, Oregon Game Lab is a labor of love; for the game design community, for the creative spirit, and for all that is and can be experienced on the tabletop. In order to bring programming such as occurs during GameStorm, Stumpquest, and The Victory Condition to life, we rely upon those who share our love of games to volunteer their time. 
 
In service to this group I oversee the: 
- expansion of scope (through additional events and organizational partnerships) 
- refinement of artifacts (by recruiting talent and guiding production) 
- evolution of ad strategy (by expanding the range of targeted demographics and associated messaging) Game Designer & Consultant Robert LaCosse LLC July 2011  – Present (4 years 2 months) Vancouver, OR Having thoroughly invested myself in the quest to gain a comprehensive understanding of game design (psychology, fabrication, mechanics, et al.) since I was 12, I believe I have attained a level of mastery that allows me to self-identify as a Game Designer. To augment my knowledge base in an academic context, I wrote an independent study while at the Art Institute of Portland, which saw the creation of the Deluvia card game.  
 
Current projects include: 
Deluvia - An Alt-Victorian card game in which players represent heads of waring factions, send airships to capture opponents' locations, and cobble technologies together to build a time machine to alter the course of the past and move the state of the present in their favor. 
 
In The Afterward - A card game in which players assemble clues from past lives and leverage cognitive tools to reveal the great meaning behind their present existence.  
 
Fluff the Mark - Players in this card game take command of their own design agency. As such, they must draw cards from the resource pool to discover contract opportunities, locate talent, and identify ways of undermining their competitors. 
 
Meme: The Game - Meme challenges players to create original internet phenomena, caption them, and vote for who has the most viral potential. Players draw from a central deck, which consists of nouns, adjectives, verbs, and wild cards, and assemble a string which all players caption and then vote upon. 
 
Amulet Arcanus - A LARP in which players take on the role of a wizard or cleric, with unique spells and abilities commensurate with their class, and face off against a number of foes in an epic quest for an all-powerful amulet. 
 
Danger&Play - A Lovecraftian murder mystery for up to 20 players that incorporates up to 11 plot points each containing between 2 and 8 characters. Deception, collusion, and ultimately murder are all in the cards for players seeking the most dangerous plaything. Event Liaison Design Week Portland July 2012  – Present (3 years 2 months) Portland, Oregon Area For 2013, I took it upon myself to ensure the Portland game design community was incorporated into the scope of Design Week. This manifested as StumpQuest Games Fest, which spanned 4 days of activities including tabletop play testing, a "gateway" games open play, an indie game arcade, and a documentary screening. Will Lewis (Portland Indie Game Squad) proved to be an amazing partner on this project and I look forward to running a similar set of programming in 2014. 
 
For DWP 2012, I functioned as both an Event Liaison and Fabrication Team Director.  
 
As FTD, I took it upon myself to: 
- collaborate with graphic/web designers to create the building specs for construction of the stage letters, light box with interchangeable face plates, type-truck rack, and sandwich boards based upon existing 2D designs 
- acquire all necessary materials and coordinate essential services for fabrication efforts 
- recruit individuals to the team 
- coordinate simultaneous fabrication processes executed by members of the team 
- take a hands-on approach whenever possible 
- maintain close contact with DWP leadership 
- track and assemble a detailed expense report 
 
As an Event Liaison I: 
- created Fashion Speaks in collaboration with Cassie Ridgway of Mag-Big 
- spearheaded communications with organizers of the IDSA 3by10 
- investigated potential collaboration with CHIFOO Storm Brewer Saüse Authenticity Agency August 2012  –  June 2013  (11 months) Portland, Oregon Area Project Management, Recruiting, Client Management, Communications, Storm Crowing, Brand Strategy, Design Research 
 
Rest is for the deceased. My lingering youth serves as a mandate for me to leverage my time wisely and productively. When I am not at Intel, I am here, doing anything and everything that needs to be done. User Experience Designer Usability Architects (on assignment to Intel) June 2012  –  May 2013  (1 year) Amberglen I am a green badge (contract worker), working as part of Intel's User Experience Product Design Team under the direction of Leo Frishberg. My day to day schedule is filled with activities ranging from user interviews and data analysis to psychological research and interaction design. In all activities, I aim to create the most actionable, profitable, and engaging products possible. I am a highly adaptive creature who is at home in the fluidity of contractual work opportunities. Intern Enet Press February 2012  –  May 2012  (4 months) Tutor, Department Respresentative, Database Administrator EDMC November 2009  –  April 2012  (2 years 6 months) 1122 Northwest Davis Street Portland, OR 97209 During my time as a student at the Art Institute of Portland, I have done many jobs. Most frequently, students could find me in the tutoring center, where I was available and able to provide instructional assistance with writing, research, HTML and CSS programming, design fundamentals, Adobe Creative Suite, fabrication processes, and Rhino 3D CAD modeling. Societies:  University of Iowa Dean's List ,  National Dean's List ,  University of Iowa Freethinkers ,  The Walt Whitman Archive Project Honors & Awards Lecturer Webvisions (PDX) May 2014 Welcome to the Ludic Century: 
 
Why do we play? That is the essential question. In answering it we discover not only where we have come from, but where we are going. Environmental circumstances have remained constant for several thousand years (arguably since the dawn of mankind) and certain games have arisen to either mimic or supplement our daily routines (whether warfare or other, more collaborative thinking, activity). However, now, we find ourselves in unfamiliar territory. It is for this reason that we are, truly, at the dawn of the Ludic Century. 
 
At our hip is what scholars of old may refer to as the "magician’s assistant". It holds access to all the knowledge of mankind and more. It gives us a gateway into the lives of untold others. 
 
In an effort to utilize this great power and bridge the gap across hundreds of miles of separation, we now have a responsibility to build games like never before. They are games which impart experiences, rather than seek a single victor. They demand their players access and evolve whole new parts of their emotive and empathic complex. They are the games that signal the Age of Play ushered in on the shoulders of the Internet of Things. 
 
Let’s talk about this. Lecturer CHIFOO November 2013 As part of the "Quantifying Kick-Ass" 2013 lecture series, I delivered "Authentically Kick Ass" which detailed the nature of authenticity and how games enable a new level of UX strategy in their ability to repeatedly produce authentic experiences. Graduation Speaker The Art Institute of Portland June 2012 I was "overwhelming nominated" by the administration to be the graduation speaker for my class. It can be found on my website and, more directly, here: http://vimeo.com/44785271 Certificate of Appreciation Northwest Career Colleges Federation 2011 To thank me for providing testimony before the Oregon House Subcommittee on Higher Education in support of the efficacy of career colleges, I was granted a certificate to the above effect. Dean's List The Art Institute of Portland January 2011 During the Honors’ Recognition Ceremony on January 26th, I was recognized for outstanding academic performance. Winter Scholarship The Art Institute Of Portland December 2010 In recognition of outstanding academic performance and, in conjunction, with a letter of recommendation from Jamie Hurd, the Industrial Design Department Director at that time, I was awarded Ai's Winter Scholarship.
